name: Onion Kulcha
history: Onion Kulcha is a variation of the traditional Kulcha, a popular North Indian flatbread. It is an amalgamation of Kulcha bread with a savory onion filling, making it a delightful and flavorful meal accompaniment.
description: Onion Kulcha is a type of leavened bread stuffed with a spiced onion filling. Made from refined flour and yeast, it's soft and fluffy on the inside with a crispy exterior. It's typically baked or cooked on a griddle and served with curries or chutneys.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. Let it sit for 10 minutes until frothy. In a mixing bowl, combine flour, salt, and yogurt. Add the yeast mixture and knead into a soft dough. Cover and let it rest for 2-3 hours.

instructions.title: Make the Filling
instructions.description: Mix chopped onions, green chilies, coriander leaves, and cumin seeds for the filling.

instructions.title: Stuff and Roll the Kulchas
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Flatten each ball, place a portion of the filling in the center, and seal it. Roll out each stuffed ball into a flat circular shape.

instructions.title: Cook the Kulchas
instructions.description: Heat a tawa or skillet. Cook each kulcha until golden brown on both sides. Brush with ghee or butter.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the hot onion kulchas with curries, dals, or chutneys.

tips: Ensure the dough is well-rested for soft kulchas.
Cook on medium heat to prevent burning while ensuring the kulchas are cooked through.
variations: Experiment with different fillings like spiced potatoes, paneer, or cheese.
Add spices like ajwain or dried fenugreek leaves to the dough for additional flavor.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh but can be stored in an airtight container for up to 24 hours.
storage.instructions: Reheat on a skillet before serving if stored.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on a hot skillet or tawa until warm and soft.
presentationTips: Serve on a decorative platter with a side of fresh salad or raita.
Garnish with additional butter or ghee for a rich flavor.
